reasoning:
The critique targets one sub-claim in the essay’s Section 3: that on unbounded linear (resource-additive) views, being mostly-great requires capturing/using nearly all accessible resources, so a merely Milky-Way-scale future is ~1/20B of the best feasible future. This is relevant to one route to the essay’s broader conclusion that many plausible moral views are “fussy,” but it is not the whole case (the essay also argues fussiness from other sources like moral fragility, multiplicative factors, and bounded/separately-aggregating views). So centrality is moderate.

The critique’s core point—expansion can have risk/governance externalities such that marginal expected value of expansion could be negative—is a real challenge to any inference from ‘linear value in resources’ to ‘must expand to be mostly-great’ if the essay is implicitly doing an expected-value argument over realistic strategies. However, the essay’s claim is closer to a counterfactual about attained value conditional on “survival” and on capturing the accessible universe, not an all-things-considered recommendation under risk; and a linear value function alone doesn’t guarantee “aggressive expansion” is optimal under uncertainty, it just says that if you don’t expand you leave value on the table. The critique therefore weakens the necessity/implication as stated, but doesn’t refute it: the essay could reply by distinguishing (i) maximum achievable value in a given realised future from (ii) optimal policy under expansion risk; or by conditioning on successful expansion without increasing existential risk (already partly in their survival conditioning). Hence limited strength.

Correctness is fairly high: it is true that expansion could increase accident surface area, conflict, and lock-in risks, and that this could break a naive “more resources always higher expected value” move. Minor overreach: it calls this a “quantitative cliff” and suggests it contradicts “necessity,” but the essay’s scale argument is about comparative magnitude under linear aggregation, not a strict policy requirement.

Clarity is high and it stays on one issue with little extraneous material. Dead weight is low.
title: Expansion externalities may make scale-maximization value-reducing
